**G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7 3**.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in this Court pursuant to **G.L. c. 185C, § 3**, as this matter involves a residential tenancy and alleged violations of Massachusetts landlord-tenant law occurring within Suffolk County.

**105 C.M.R. 410.000 (State Sanitary Cod.proposition: As the condition persisted, Plaintiff contacted the **City of Boston Inspectional Services Department**, which inspected the unit and confirmed the existence of **water penetration and other housing code violations**, in violation of **105 C.M.R. 410.000 (State Sanitary Code)**.

**G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14**.proposition: Under **G.L. c. 186, § 14**, a landlord is prohibited from “directly or indirectly interfering with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant.”

**Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway*.proposition: Defendant’s actions and omissions are further prohibited under **Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway**, 363 Mass. 184 (1973), which holds that the covenant of quiet enjoyment is breached by any act or failure to act that materially impairs the character and value of the leased premises.
**Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway*.support_reasoning: The excerpt is a concurring/dissenting opinion focused on implied warranty of habitability and statutory housing-code duties, not on the covenant of quiet enjoyment. The quoted text does not discuss quiet enjoyment at all, nor articulate a standard that any act or omission materially impairing character and value of the premises constitutes a breach of that covenant. While the full case of Hemingway elsewhere is known for expanding tenant protections, this particular text does not provide authority for the specific quiet enjoyment proposition cited.
**Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway*.relevant_excerpt: "The opinion of the court in the present cases does not discuss or otherwise deal with the rule quoted above from Palmigiani v. D’Argento... As the first step in the removal of the roadblock discussed above I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards..."

**G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 18**.proposition: Defendant’s retaliatory conduct, manifested by the threat not to renew Plaintiff’s lease following his lawful complaints to municipal authorities, also constitutes a violation of **G.L. c. 186, § 18** (retaliatory eviction statute), evidencing interference with quiet enjoyment as defined in **Blackett v. Olanoff**, 371 Mass. 714 (1977).

**Blackett v. Olanoff**, 371 Mass. 714 (.proposition: Defendant’s retaliatory conduct, manifested by the threat not to renew Plaintiff’s lease following his lawful complaints to municipal authorities, also constitutes a violation of **G.L. c. 186, § 18** (retaliatory eviction statute), evidencing interference with quiet enjoyment as defined in **Blackett v. Olanoff**, 371 Mass. 714 (1977).
**Blackett v. Olanoff**, 371 Mass. 714 (.support_reasoning: Blackett v. Olanoff concerns constructive eviction and breach of the common-law implied covenant of quiet enjoyment due to excessive noise from a bar operated on premises the landlord controlled. The opinion does not discuss G.L. c. 186, § 18, retaliatory eviction, lease nonrenewal, or retaliation for complaints to municipal authorities. Using Blackett as authority that a landlord’s retaliatory nonrenewal violates § 18 misstates the case’s scope; it addresses interference with quiet enjoyment, not statutory retaliatory conduct or threats not to renew a lease.
**Blackett v. Olanoff**, 371 Mass. 714 (.relevant_excerpt: “Our opinions concerning a constructive eviction by an alleged breach of an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment sometimes have stated that the landlord must perform some act with the intent of depriving the tenant of the enjoyment and occupation of the whole or part of the leased premises… There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.”

**Al-Ziab v. Mourgis**, 424 Mass. 847 (1.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that a landlord’s **failure to correct sanitary code violations** may give rise to damages for breach of quiet enjoyment.
**Al-Ziab v. Mourgis**, 424 Mass. 847 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion is not primarily about sanitary code violations, but in explaining the standard for liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14, the SJC expressly cites prior quiet enjoyment cases where a landlord’s failure to repair or correct known defects in violation of the sanitary code constituted a breach. The court reaffirms that a landlord’s negligent failure to repair defects of which it has notice—specifically including failure to keep an apartment in habitable condition—has "frequently" been deemed to violate § 14. That reasoning supports the general proposition that failure to correct sanitary code violations can give rise to quiet enjoyment damages.
**Al-Ziab v. Mourgis**, 424 Mass. 847 (1.relevant_excerpt: We noted that a landlord’s failure “to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.” See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so).

**Jablonski v. Casey**, 64 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that a landlord’s **failure to correct sanitary code violations** may give rise to damages for breach of quiet enjoyment.
**Jablonski v. Casey**, 64 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the covenant of quiet enjoyment in the context of alleged sanitary code violations but holds that there was no breach and no interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment. The court emphasizes that the landlord acted promptly to correct the cited conditions and explicitly rejects the tenant’s quiet enjoyment claim. It does not state or affirm a general rule that failure to correct sanitary code violations gives rise to damages for breach of quiet enjoyment; instead, it concludes the opposite on these facts.
**Jablonski v. Casey**, 64 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “Casey counterclaimed that York breached her covenant of quiet enjoyment… We have interpreted this obligation to mean that the covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant from serious interference with her tenancy… Here, York acted immediately upon being notified by Casey of the defective conditions… The trial judge did not err in denying the requested ruling of law that a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment had occurred. We see no evidence in the record before us of interference with Casey’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.”

**Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority**.raw_text: **Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority**, 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
**Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority**.proposition: Additional authority recognizes that persistent water leaks and unremedied structural issues establish a breach even absent intent.
**Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority**.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
**Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority**.support_reasoning: The case does not involve water leaks or structural defects; it concerns criminal drug activity in common areas and whether that activity, and the landlord’s failure to act, breaches statutory duties or the covenant of quiet enjoyment. The court explicitly limits the warranty of habitability to physical facilities but then holds there was no habitability breach here, and focuses any potential liability on quiet enjoyment, not on unintentional physical defects. It therefore neither addresses nor establishes that persistent water leaks or unremedied structural issues constitute a breach absent intent.
**Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority**.relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that the implied warranty of habitability is concerned with the provision, maintenance, and repair of the physical facilities vital to the use of the leased premises, and is not breached solely by the presence on the premises of uninvited persons engaged in unlawful activities or by the failure to provide security services.”

**Simon v. Solomon**, 385 Mass. 91 (1982.proposition: Additional authority recognizes that persistent water leaks and unremedied structural issues establish a breach even absent intent.
**Simon v. Solomon**, 385 Mass. 91 (1982.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly treats repeated flooding from water and sewage, caused by a porous wall and failure to keep the apartment watertight, as a breach of the landlord’s duties under the implied warranty of habitability and the sanitary code. The court further notes that such a breach can abate rent obligations even when the landlord is not at fault and has no reasonable opportunity to repair, thereby recognizing that persistent leaks and structural defects can establish breach without requiring intentional misconduct.
**Simon v. Solomon**, 385 Mass. 91 (1982.relevant_excerpt: “We have held that every landlord that rents residential property warrants to its tenants that the premises will be delivered and maintained in a habitable condition…. A landlord’s breach of this duty abates the tenant’s obligation to pay rent, even when the landlord is not at fault and has no reasonable opportunity to make repairs. … There was evidence at trial that the wall between Solomon’s apartment and the adjoining basement area was extremely porous. … Further, a section of the State Sanitary Code…provides that apartments must be watertight.”

**Young v. Patukonis**, 24 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Additional authority recognizes that persistent water leaks and unremedied structural issues establish a breach even absent intent.
**Young v. Patukonis**, 24 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion mentions numerous sanitary code violations and acknowledges a breach of the warranty of habitability, but it does not discuss persistent water leaks or unremedied structural issues in the way described by the proposition. The decision focuses on damages and the method of calculating rent abatement, not on establishing a rule that such conditions constitute a breach regardless of intent. There is no specific holding that persistent water leaks or structural problems, standing alone and without intent, establish a breach, so this citation does not substantively support the claimed proposition.
**Young v. Patukonis**, 24 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “Several violations of the State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. § 410.000 (1983), have existed in the tenant’s apartment since Young and his mother acquired the property… The judge concluded, however, that most of the conditions had minimal impact on the use and enjoyment of the apartment and that Young had been fairly responsive to the tenant’s requests for repairs.… Patukonis challenges the judge’s award of $625 in damages for the breach of warranty of habitability… The judge properly could have disregarded the minor code violations.”

**Lowery v. Robinson**, 13 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment “protects tenants against acts or omissions by the landlord that impair the character or value of the leasehold.” **Lowery v. Robinson**, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982).
**Lowery v. Robinson**, 13 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that a landlord’s failure to provide heat “seriously impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises” and that this constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. The court ties this directly to G.L. c. 186, § 14 and relies on that impairment of character and value as the basis for finding a violation, squarely supporting the proposition that the covenant protects tenants against acts or omissions by the landlord that impair the character or value of the leasehold.
**Lowery v. Robinson**, 13 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season… seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’ (Winchester v. O’Brien, 266 Mass. 33, 36 [1929], quoting from Brande v. Grace, 154 Mass. 210, 212 [1891]), and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

**G.L. c. 239, \u00a7 8A**.proposition: Defendant’s failure to act also violates the warranty of habitability recognized in **Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway**, supra, and the statutory obligations of landlords under **G.L. c. 239, § 8A** and **G.L. c. 186, § 14**.
